points.content: Supervised by Saloni Potdar
I used TensorFlow to build a language models for language agnostic intent detection, designed to work with Watson Language Assistant.
The work was based on BERT-multi, USE, FastText.
With Dylan Pentland, and Fransesc Fite. Supervised by Andrew Sutherland
We found a practical algorithm for computing the L-polynomial of a Picard curve, which runs in O(log^3 p) time.
This is the first practical result of this type for curves with genus greater than 3.
This enables the (previously impossible) computation of certain Sato Tate distributions and groups.
The algorithms are implemented the algorithm in Python using Sage and then a faster implementation in C using the PARI library.
Supervised by Ilker Yildrim
I used primate data visual cortex data to build deep neural nets, which achieved high accuracy on standard benchmarks like COCO.
Our model was motivated by evolution, and then optimized to achieve a high correlation with primate data.
These results were respectable but have since been surpassed.
With Jason Lynch. Supervised by Erik Demaine.

I worked on extending techniques in energy-efficient algorithms (solving computationally intensive problems using vastly less energy consumption) to data structures used in text web searches. I also worked on the theoretical complexity of games and proved a long-standing conjecture.
First in Pakistan
First in Pakistan
ooh ooh aah aah cupcakes
ooh ooh aah aah cupcakes
'Applied Rationality' camp, 10 days with ~30 people. See this website for more info.
This was a very impactful experience in many ways and I am throughly grateful for it.
Competed for Pakistan.
Competed in HackMIT and various other hackathons.

I developed organization-level strategy and project-management for the team of 50+ volunteers that built a platform for COVID-specific mask awareness in Pakistan. We reached 20 million social media impressions and provided 75k+ masks to people in poverty in Pakistan.
Visit this website for our work. I also led the web-development team in the project.
We collaborated with the local government, dozens of local NGO's and companies for reaching out at the root-level in Pakistan for awareness.
Our work was archived by the Library of Congress in social awareness efforts for COVID relief.

This has been one of the most formative experiences of my life. We worked day and night in preparation for Pakistan becoming one of the major hotspots of the pandemic. I am extremely proud and thankful to have worked with our team that worked day and night to make alot of this happen. Our work is still on-going on social media.
I designed schedules, lectures, assignments, and selection tests for Pakistan’s 50 top students.
I handled last-minute logistical problems, tutored, graded, and analyzed performance data.
I planned and taught biweekly problem solving practice sessions for 12 freshmen and 8 juniors.
Five of my students made Top 50, three made Top 20, and one made the IMO team alongside me.

Taught by Professor David Jerison and John Bush
I taught a recitation with 22 students for the MIT's accelerated calculus GIR (General Institute Requirement).
I wrote solutions for and graded problem-sets, led weekly office-hours and tried to built good mathematical calculus and problem-solving intuitions in my students.
Covid Teaching has been quite interesting. I found that connecting with students on a personal level and making them feel at home significantly helps with teaching.
Taught by Silvina Hanono Wachman, Daniel Sanchez, Joel Emer and Song Han.
I helped develop and evaluate submitted labs. I also supported students at office hours.
